Document Sources.Sourced Statement: As of October 2023, 26 states and the District of Columbia had expanded voting rights to people living with felony convictions, according to The Sentencing Project, a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The bill, introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne, passed by a wide margin in the last year of Wayne’s second term.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The passage of the bill “means everything for the thousands of people who have not been full participants in society,” said TJ King, a Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink who was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink who was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: King said the bill’s passage is the final layer in his ability to be civically engaged and “have a full voice and complete connection to the community.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink who was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Studies have shown that if you allow people to engage in their community upon being released, the recidivism rate drops,” Wayne said during a public hearing for the bill last year.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We spend on average $42,000 a year on prisoners, of which we have around a 30 percent recidivism rate.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “One year, I brought in a little chart that says if we just cut it by 10 percent, we’re saving around $5 million a year.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: As a result, voting rights have been restored to over 2 million people, said Nicole Porter, senior director of advocacy at The Sentencing Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior director of advocacy at The Sentencing Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: senior director of advocacy at The Sentencing Project

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Republican Gov. Jim Pillen’s office did not immediately respond to messages Thursday by The Associated Press asking whether he would sign the bill into law.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Republican Gov. Jim Pillen’s office did not immediately respond to messages Thursday by The Associated Press asking whether he would sign the bill into law

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Florida, lawmakers weakened a 2018 voter-approved constitutional amendment to restore the voting rights of most convicted felons.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: In Florida, lawmakers weakened a 2018 voter-approved constitutional amendment to restore the voting rights of most convicted felons

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Following that, an election police unit championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis arrested 20 former felons.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: an election police unit championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Following that, an election police unit championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis arrested 20 former felons

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Tennessee, lawmakers on Wednesday killed a bipartisan bill for the year that would have let residents convicted of felonies apply to vote again without also restoring their gun rights.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: In Tennessee, lawmakers on Wednesday killed a bipartisan bill for the year that would have let residents convicted of felonies apply to vote again without also restoring their gun rights
